text:
mod_negotiation seems to have unpleasant and uncontrolled interactions with
RedirectMatch.  Here's one example: take an empty directory on a fresh standard
Apache configuration.  Add the MultiViews option and AllowOverride All.  Create
a file called, say, "google2.txt" (see URI on this bug report for an example),
but do _not_ create a file called "google2".  Further create a .htaccess file
containing the single line "RedirectMatch Permanent google2.*$
http://www.google.com/" (see the .htaccess file in the URI on this bug report,
which is publicly readable).  Now use a browser and try to access "google2"
(with no extension) in the directory in question.  This results in a 404 error
saying "google2" does not exist.  This is true, of course, but the behavior is
unacceptable: either the RedirectMatch should be heeded before MultiViews (in
which case the browser should be redirected to Google) or after (in which case
google2 should be treated as google2.txt but should anyway be redirected to
Google); but the 404 error should certainly not occur.

Note that if the file "google2.txt" does not exist (see the example of "google1"
from the URI on this bug report) or on the contrary if the file "google2" _does_
exist (see the example of "google3" from the URI) then the redirection works as
expected.

I am told that even stranger things can happen if some files are actually
directories.  I have not tested this.
